Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Feasibility of Using Speech as Biomarker for Concussions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies the feasibility of using speech as a novel biomarker for concussions, based on insights obtained from prior research that have shown links between impaired brain functioning and speech. Mild traumatic brain injuries (mTBI) such as concussions are arguably one of the most pressing concerns in sports today, with an estimated 2-4 million cases every year in youth sports alone. The potential short- and long-term impacts on the health and well-being of individuals with brain injuries are extensive. Untreated concussions can lead to diseases such as chronic traumatic encephalopathy, an elevated incidence of Alzheimer's disease, and dementia developing at a higher rate and a younger age. It is therefore imperative to accurately detect and appropriately treat mTBI, especially among adolescents, whose brains are still developing and more prone to long-term damage.

This research advances the understanding of the relationship between brain injuries and acoustic features in speech and lays the foundation for novel and accurate concussion screening tools. Initial results based on voice collections from more than 300 boxers (25 of which were concussed) have been promising and indicate that speech may have the potential to serve as a new, easy-to-capture biomarker for mTBI. Using mobile technologies such as smartphones and tablets, brief speech recordings from youth athletes are being captured. With the help of speech recognition techniques, each word is isolated and acoustic features are extracted for each phoneme in each word. Features that are being analyzed include temporal characteristics of speech (e.g., speech duration per word or phoneme or articulation rate) and frequency spectrum characteristics (e.g., pitch, formant frequencies, and mel-frequency cepstrum coefficients). Using state-of-the-art statistical analysis and machine learning techniques, these features are then analyzed for their potential as marker for mild forms of brain injuries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Concussions are one of the most pressing concerns in sports and military today, with an estimated 2-4 million cases every year in youth sports alone. The potential short- and long-term impacts on the health and wellbeing of individuals with brain injuries are extensive and untreated concussions have been shown to lead to diseases such as chronic traumatic encephalopathy, an elevated incidence of Alzheimer's disease, and dementia developing at a higher rate and a younger age. The main goal of the project was to study the feasibility of using acoustic features in the human voice to detect signs of brain injuries, specifically focusing on mild traumatic brain injuries (mTBI) or concussions. Specifically, the purpose of the project was to collect speech samples from youth athletes participating in various forms of contact sports, identify a variety of acoustic features that could be used as concussion biomarkers, develop the required speech processing algorithms to extract these features, and study which features appear to be most impacted by a potential mTBI. With the help of the National Science Foundation, a tablet-based concussion test was developed and speech recordings from over 2,500 youth athletes (from about 50 high schools and colleges) were collected, which included data from 107 concussed athletes. The data was used to identify patterns in speech that can indicate a potential concussion. Traditional machine learning and deep learning techniques were used to analyze the speech data and the resulting concussion detection accuracies ranged from 85-90%, depending on the machine learning technique used.
